result.execSummary:
The defendant Edward C. Decorah was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Credit Card-Forgery (Alteration, etc.) [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.41(4)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Portage County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes: Consecutive to: any sentence he is serving if he is revoked.

miscConds.notes: Pay fine of $150 plus costs including the DNA surcharge.

Pay restitution in the amount of $900.99, joint and several with Mato Montelongo. 
Bond to be applied to restitution then fine and costs. 
If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Pursue fulltime employment or schooling or combination of both.  School or combination applies after the restitution has been paid in full.  Employment is if he is able and Court asks the agent to review the defendant's disability situation.

Participate in any counseling deemed appropriate by the agent. 
If defendant has not already provided a DNA sample, then he will have to provide a sample.
***Amended: BY THE COURT on 07-22-15:
Defendant to pay $50.00 per month towards his court obligations.
Defendant informed to work with his Probation Agent.
Defendant has a 1:00 p.m. appointment with the Probation Agent on July 23, 2015 and he is to provide her with his monthly budget and set up a 
payment plan with his agent.  Probation Agent can request a future review hearing if necessary.***

records.descr: Notice of court ordered financial obligations

records.addlTxt: from Probation Agent

Defendant Edward C. Decorah in court. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

3:27 p.m.  Court calls case.
This case is set for a Review Hearing at 4:00 p.m. but Atty Constable is willing to do early.
Clerk calls the probation officer, Joan Hawke as she wished to appear via telephone.
Defendant would like to proceed prior to 4:00 as he has a new job he will be starting in Wisconsin Rapids.
Probation Officer and all other parties in the courtroom are able to proceed early.
Court makes statements regarding the defendant meeting his Court obligations.
Court questions the defendant if he had received the Probation Office's Memorandum; Defenant indicates that he does not know what that is.
Court reviews the case with the defendant and reads the memorandum to the defendant.
Court questions the probation officer if the memorandum that was read in Court was accurate; Probation Officer indicates that the defendant did make a payment after the memorandum had been mailed.
Probation Officer states that a payment of $20.00 and was applied to his account on July 10, 2015.
Court questions the Probation Officer as to when the last payment had been received.
Defendant makes argument regarding payments not being made and states that there was a $1,000 that had been posted but this had been paid towards restitution.
Court questions how that explains why he has not been able to pay any of his other Court ordered obligations.
Court questions the defendant.
Defendant will be working at HoChunk Casino at 4 hrs/week at $10/hour.   
Defendant will be providing his agent with the budget he has brought to Court today.
Probation Officer states that she had wanted the defendant to commit to a $50/month payment but he has not done that; HoChunk Casino job is temporary.
Court questions the defendant as to when he was planning on looking for another job as the HoChunk Casino job is temporary.
Defendant states that his monthly income does not cover his monthly expenses.
Court reviews the expenses/income of the defendant and indicates that the defendant should be able to make at least a $60/month payment.
Defendant questions if he would be able to make a $40/month payment for his court obligations.
State does not wish to make a statement.
Probation Agent states that the defendant should have been making his monthly payments.
Defendant had indicated that he had memory issues and Court informed him that he needs to find ways to deal with the memory issues.

BY THE COURT:
Defendant to pay $50.00 per month towards his court obligations.
Defendant informed to work with his Probation Agent.
Defendant has a 1:00 p.m. appointment with the Probation Agent on July 23, 2015 and he is to provide her with his monthly budget and set up a 
payment plan with his agent.
Probation Agent can request a future review hearing if necessary.
Review hearing at 07-22-2015 04:00 pm

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Edward C. Decorah in court with attorney Adam Raabe. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
  
Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
State has complied with Victim Notification Statutes.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of:  
Count 1 - NO CONTEST

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty Count 1.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Counts 2 & 3 are dismissed and read-in. 

Atty Constable makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Raabe makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

BY THE COURT:
9 months jail, consecutive to any sentence he is serving if he is revoked.  2 days credit. Stayed
Placed on probation for a period of 24 months:
Pay $150 fine plus costs including the DNA surcharge. 
Pay restitution in the amoutn of $900.99 joint and several with Mato Montelongo.
Restitution to be taken from any bond that has been posted.  Balance to the fine and costs. 
Pursue fulltime employment or schooling or combination of both.  School or combination applies after the restitution has been paid in full. Employment is if he is able and Court asks the agent to review the defendant's disability situation. 
Participate in any counseling deemed appropriate by the agent. 
If defendant has not already provided a DNA sample, then he will have to provide a sample. 

Atty Constable asks for 30 days to reach a stipulation on jail credit. 
Atty Raabe indicates he believes it is 2 days. 

BY THE COURT: 
Court grants 2 days jail credit.
Plea hearing on October 29, 2014 at 08:30 am.
Pre-trial conference on September 29, 2014 at 08:30 am.

Pre-trial conference on August 18, 2014 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Edward C. Decorah in court with attorney Adam Raabe. Veronica Isherwood appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
  Defendant waives right to Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions the Defendant regarding Waiver of Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions Defendant's attorney.
Court finds the Defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the Preliminary Hearing.
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial. 
  Arraignment:
State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information. 
Not Guilty Plea entered.
Bond Continued  Pre-trial conference scheduled for August 18, 2014 at 08:30 am.
Preliminary hearing on June 30, 2014 at 03:00 pm.

Defendant Edward C. Decorah in court with attorney Adam Raabe.  Intern Kraus w/ADA Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
  Defendant/Attorney received copy of Criminal Complaint and waived its reading.
Court informs Defendant of Charges and maximum penalties.
Time limits not waived.
Bond continued.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for June 30, 2014 at 03:00 pm.
for 06-16-14...continued from 06-12-14
Do not have direct/indirect contact with the following persons/places:  Trig's

Defendant Edward C. Decorah not in court, defendant in custody. Cass Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

2:21 p.m.  Court calls case.
Atty Cousins states the appearances.
Court informs the defendants of the penalties on each count.
Defendant has received a copy of the complaint.
Defendant has  contacted the Public Defender; states is eligible for a Public Defender.
Defendant states he was assigned Atty Adam Raabe.
State is requesting a $1,000.00 cash bond; no direct/indirect contact with Trig's.
Atty Cousins states the address of the Defendant is currently unknown as different addresses had been provided by the Defendant.
Defendant states he is living with his sister at S653 Oakhill Lane in Wisconsin Dells, WI.
Defendant is currently employed but not able to pay a $1,000.00 cash bond.
Court asks Defendant if he can post any cash bond and states he does not.

BY THE COURT:
Cash bail set in amount of $1,000.00 with no direct/indirect contact with TRIG'S.
Defendant is remanded back to the Portage County Jail.
Continued Initial Appearance set for June 16, 2014.
